PROCEDURES
The first step in the development of this study was the
meeting of the Research Committee late in 1963. There was
agreement among the members of the Committee that the most
useful approach to uncovering the needed information would
be to conduct a mail questionnaire survey of the individuals
t
who had listed "research" as an area of competency in the
personnel survey conducted earlier by the NAEB.~*
More than 900 individuals listed "research" as a comÂ¬
petency in the NAEB personnel study. It was decided to sample
approximately one-third of this total, but at the same time
send this list of the selected sample to each person in the
initial mailing. Space would be provided for respondents to
list anyone else engaged in radio-television research whose
name did not appear on the list. Questionnaires would then
be sent to these additional individuals. This, combined with
the exhaustive efforts of the NAEB personnel study, would
provide the assurance that anyone involved in research in
educational broadcasting would be contacted. This would also
achieve one of the goals of the study, that of building a
roster of people who are currently engaged in research projects.
Bronson and Fellows, op. cit.
